values.comments:
MKTG 476 exposes students to the theoretical and empirical "building blocks" that will allow them to construct, estimate, and interpret powerful models of customer behavior. Over the years, researchers and practitioners have used these models for a wide variety of applications, such as new product sales, forecasting, analyses of media usage, and targeted marketing programs. Other disciplines have seen equally broad utilization of these techniques. The course is entirely lecture-based with a strong emphasis on real-time problem solving. Most sessions feature sophisticated numerical investigations using Microsoft Excel. Much of the material is highly technical. The course is cross-listed with STAT 476 and MKTG 776.
Students called MKTG 476 “the best course at Wharton,” “the best course I have taken at any level in my academic career,” and “a life-changing course.” One student mentioned that the course supplies “cutting-edge, highly applicable knowledge.” The class does have a high work requirement and requires familiarity with certain mathematical and statistical concepts. One student pointed out that the material was very “theoretical,” and would have appreciated more “applications of models.”
Reviews for Professor Fader were very positive. Professor Fader was described as “simply excellent” and “at the top of the field with what he does.” “He challenges students to try their hand in developing their own models, frameworks, and unique applications.” One student did mention that he enjoyed the “wit and sarcasm” Professor Fader employed in class but would have appreciated more guidance on why a certain idea is “wrong” or “incorrect.”
MKTG 476 is an elective course that is cross listed in the Statistics department. Students “strongly recommend this course to anyone pursuing an even slightly analytic major.”
